org.apache.freemarker.core

Class MutableParsingAndProcessingConfiguration<SelfT extends MutableParsingAndProcessingConfiguration<SelfT>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.freemarker.core.MutableProcessingConfiguration<SelfT>
      • org.apache.freemarker.core.MutableParsingAndProcessingConfiguration<SelfT>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ParsingAndProcessingConfiguration, ParsingConfiguration, ProcessingConfiguration
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Configuration.ExtendableBuilder, TemplateConfiguration.Builder

    public abstract class MutableParsingAndProcessingConfiguration<SelfT extends MutableParsingAndProcessingConfiguration<SelfT>>
extends MutableProcessingConfiguration<SelfT>
implements ParsingAndProcessingConfiguration

    • Method Detail

      • setSetting

        public void setSetting(String name,
                       String value)
                throws ConfigurationException
        Description copied from class: MutableProcessingConfiguration
        Sets a FreeMarker setting by a name and string value. If you can configure FreeMarker directly with Java (or other programming language), you should use the dedicated setter methods instead (like MutableProcessingConfiguration.setTimeZone(TimeZone). This meant to be used only when you get settings from somewhere as String-String name-value pairs (typically, as a Properties object). Below you find an overview of the settings available.

        Note: As of FreeMarker 2.3.23, setting names can be written in camel case too. For example, instead of dateFormat you can also use dateFormat. It's likely that camel case will become to the recommended convention in the future.

        The list of settings commonly supported in all MutableProcessingConfiguration subclasses:

        • "locale": See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setLocale(Locale).
          String value: local codes with the usual format in Java, such as "en_US", or "JVM default" (ignoring case) to use the default locale of the Java environment.

        • "customNumberFormat": See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setCustomNumberFormats(Map).
          String value: Interpreted as an object builder expression.
          Example: { "hex": com.example.HexTemplateNumberFormatFactory, "gps": com.example.GPSTemplateNumberFormatFactory }

        • "customDateFormat": See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setCustomDateFormats(Map).
          String value: Interpreted as an object builder expression.
          Example: { "trade": com.example.TradeTemplateDateFormatFactory, "log": com.example.LogTemplateDateFormatFactory }

        • "templateExceptionHandler": See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setTemplateExceptionHandler(TemplateExceptionHandler).
          String value: If the value contains dot, then it's interpreted as an object builder expression. If the value does not contain dot, then it must be one of these predefined values (case insensitive): "rethrow" (means TemplateExceptionHandler.RETHROW), "debug" (means TemplateExceptionHandler.DEBUG), "htmlDebug" (means TemplateExceptionHandler.HTML_DEBUG), "ignore" (means TemplateExceptionHandler.IGNORE), or "default" (only allowed for Configuration instances) for the default.

        • "attemptExceptionReporter": See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setAttemptExceptionReporter(AttemptExceptionReporter).
          String value: If the value contains dot, then it's interpreted as an object builder expression. If the value does not contain dot, then it must be one of these predefined values (case insensitive): "logError" (means AttemptExceptionReporter.LOG_ERROR), "logWarn" (means AttemptExceptionReporter.LOG_WARN), or "default" (only allowed for Configuration instances) for the default value.

        • "arithmeticEngine": See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setArithmeticEngine(ArithmeticEngine).
          String value: If the value contains dot, then it's interpreted as an object builder expression. If the value does not contain dot, then it must be one of these special values (case insensitive): "bigdecimal", "conservative".

        • "objectWrapper": See Configuration.ExtendableBuilder.setObjectWrapper(ObjectWrapper).
          String value: If the value contains dot, then it's interpreted as an object builder expression, with the addition that DefaultObjectWrapper, DefaultObjectWrapper and RestrictedObjectWrapper can be referred without package name. For example, these strings are valid values: "DefaultObjectWrapper(3.0.0)", "RestrictedObjectWrapper(3.0.0)". "com.example.MyObjectWrapper(1, 2, someProperty=true, otherProperty=false)".
          It also accepts the special value (case insensitive) "default".
          It also accepts the special value (case insensitive) "default".

        • "numberFormat": See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setNumberFormat(String).

        • "booleanFormat": See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setBooleanFormat(String) .

        • "dateFormat", "dateFormat", "dateTimeFormat": See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setDateFormat(String), MutableProcessingConfiguration.setTimeFormat(String), MutableProcessingConfiguration.setDateTimeFormat(String).

        • "timeZone": See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setTimeZone(TimeZone).
          String value: With the format as TimeZone.getTimeZone(java.lang.String) defines it. Also, since 2.3.21 "JVM default" can be used that will be replaced with the actual JVM default time zone when MutableProcessingConfiguration.setSetting(String, String) is called. For example "GMT-8:00" or "America/Los_Angeles"
          If you set this setting, consider setting sqlDateAndTimeTimeZone too (see below)!

        • sqlDateAndTimeTimeZone: See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setSQLDateAndTimeTimeZone(TimeZone). Since 2.3.21.
          String value: With the format as TimeZone.getTimeZone(java.lang.String) defines it. Also, "JVM default" can be used that will be replaced with the actual JVM default time zone when MutableProcessingConfiguration.setSetting(String, String) is called. Also "null" can be used, which has the same effect as setSQLDateAndTimeTimeZone(null).

        • "outputEncoding": See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setOutputEncoding(Charset).

        • "urlEscapingCharset": See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setURLEscapingCharset(Charset).

        • "autoFlush": See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setAutoFlush(boolean). Since 2.3.17.
          String value: "true", "false", "y", etc.

        • "autoImports": See Configuration.getAutoImports()
          String value is something like:
          /lib/form.ftl as f, /lib/widget as w, "/lib/odd name.ftl" as odd

        • "autoInclude": Sets the list of auto-includes. See Configuration.getAutoIncludes()
          String value is something like:
          /include/common.ftl, "/include/evil name.ftl"

        • "lazyAutoImports": See Configuration.getLazyAutoImports().
          String value: "true", "false" (also the equivalents: "yes", "no", "t", "f", "y", "n"), case insensitive. Also can be "null".

        • "lazyImports": See Configuration.getLazyImports().
          String value: "true", "false" (also the equivalents: "yes", "no", "t", "f", "y", "n"), case insensitive.

        • "newBuiltinClassResolver": See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setNewBuiltinClassResolver(TemplateClassResolver). Since 2.3.17. The value must be one of these (ignore the quotation marks):

          1. "unrestricted": Use TemplateClassResolver.UNRESTRICTED

          2. "allowNothing": Use TemplateClassResolver.ALLOW_NOTHING

          3. Something that contains colon will use OptInTemplateClassResolver and is expected to store comma separated values (possibly quoted) segmented with "allowedClasses:" and/or "trustedTemplates:". Examples of valid values:

            Setting value Meaning
            allowedClasses: com.example.C1, com.example.C2, trustedTemplates: lib/*, safe.ftl Only allow instantiating the com.example.C1 and com.example.C2 classes. But, allow templates within the lib/ directory (like lib/foo/bar.ftl) and template safe.ftl (that does not match foo/safe.ftl, only exactly safe.ftl) to instantiate anything that TemplateClassResolver.UNRESTRICTED allows.
            allowedClasses: com.example.C1, com.example.C2 Only allow instantiating the com.example.C1 and com.example.C2 classes. There are no trusted templates.
            trustedTemplates: lib/*, safe.ftl Do not allow instantiating any classes, except in templates inside lib/ or in template safe.ftl.

            For more details see OptInTemplateClassResolver.

          4. Otherwise if the value contains dot, it's interpreted as an object builder expression.

          Note that the safer option was removed in FreeMarker 3.0.0, as it has become equivalent with "unrestricted", as the classes it has blocked were removed from FreeMarker.

        • "showErrorTips": See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setShowErrorTips(boolean). Since 2.3.21.
          String value: "true", "false", "y", etc.

        • apiBuiltinEnabled: See MutableProcessingConfiguration.setAPIBuiltinEnabled(boolean). Since 2.3.22.
          String value: "true", "false", "y", etc.

        Configuration (a subclass of MutableProcessingConfiguration) also understands these:

        • "auto_escaping": See Configuration.getAutoEscapingPolicy()
          String value: "enableIfDefault" or "enableIfDefault" for AutoEscapingPolicy.ENABLE_IF_DEFAULT, "enableIfDefault" or "enableIfSupported" for AutoEscapingPolicy.ENABLE_IF_SUPPORTED "disable" for AutoEscapingPolicy.DISABLE.

        • "sourceEncoding": See Configuration.getSourceEncoding(); since 2.3.26 also accepts value "JVM default" (not case sensitive) to set the Java environment default value.
          As the default value is the system default, which can change from one server to another, you should always set this!

        • "localizedTemplateLookup": See Configuration.getLocalizedTemplateLookup().
          String value: "true", "false" (also the equivalents: "yes", "no", "t", "f", "y", "n"). ASTDirCase insensitive.

        • "outputFormat": See ParsingConfiguration.getOutputFormat().
          String value: "default" (case insensitive) for the default, or an object builder expression that gives an OutputFormat, for example HTMLOutputFormat or XMLOutputFormat.

        • "registeredCustomOutputFormats": See Configuration.getRegisteredCustomOutputFormats().
          String value: an object builder expression that gives a List of OutputFormat-s. Example: [com.example.MyOutputFormat(), com.example.MyOtherOutputFormat()]

        • "whitespaceStripping": See ParsingConfiguration.getWhitespaceStripping().
          String value: "true", "false", yes, etc.

        • "templateCacheStorage": See Configuration.getTemplateCacheStorage().
          String value: If the value contains dot, then it's interpreted as an object builder expression. If the value does not contain dot, then a MruCacheStorage will be used with the maximum strong and soft sizes specified with the setting value. Examples of valid setting values:

          Setting valuemax. strong sizemax. soft size
          "strong:50, soft:500"50500
          "strong:100, soft"100Integer.MAX_VALUE
          "strong:100"1000
          "soft:100"0100
          "strong"Integer.MAX_VALUE0
          "soft"0Integer.MAX_VALUE

          The value is not case sensitive. The order of soft and strong entries is not significant.

        • "templateUpdateDelay": Template update delay in seconds (not in milliseconds) if no unit is specified; see Configuration.getTemplateUpdateDelayMilliseconds() for more.
          String value: Valid positive integer, optionally followed by a time unit (recommended). The default unit is seconds. It's strongly recommended to specify the unit for clarity, like in "500 ms" or "30 s". Supported units are: "s" (seconds), "ms" (milliseconds), "m" (minutes), "h" (hours). The whitespace between the unit and the number is optional. Units are only supported since 2.3.23.

        • "tagSyntax": See ParsingConfiguration.getTagSyntax().
          String value: Must be one of "autoDetect", "squareBracket", and "squareBracket".

        • "incompatibleImprovements": See Configuration.getIncompatibleImprovements().
          String value: version number like 2.3.20.

        • "recognizeStandardFileExtensions": See Configuration.getRecognizeStandardFileExtensions().
          String value: "default" (case insensitive) for the default, or "true", "false", yes, etc.

        • "templateConfigurations": See: Configuration.getTemplateConfigurations().
          String value: Interpreted as an object builder expression, can be null.

        • "templateLoader": See: Configuration.getTemplateLoader().
          String value: "default" (case insensitive) for the default, or else interpreted as an object builder expression. "null" is also allowed.

        • "templateLookupStrategy": See: Configuration.getTemplateLookupStrategy().
          String value: "default" (case insensitive) for the default, or else interpreted as an object builder expression.

        • "templateNameFormat": See: Configuration.getTemplateNameFormat().
          String value: "default" (case insensitive) for the default, DefaultTemplateNameFormat.INSTANCE.

        Regarding object builder expressions (used by the setting values where it was indicated):

        • Before FreeMarker 2.3.21 it had to be a fully qualified class name, and nothing else.

        • Since 2.3.21, the generic syntax is: className(constrArg1, constrArg2, ... constrArgN, propName1=propValue1, propName2=propValue2, ... propNameN=propValueN), where className is the fully qualified class name of the instance to invoke (except if we have builder class or INSTANCE field around, but see that later), constrArg-s are the values of constructor arguments, and propName=propValue-s set JavaBean properties (like x=1 means setX(1)) on the created instance. You can have any number of constructor arguments and property setters, including 0. Constructor arguments must precede any property setters.

        • Example: com.example.MyObjectWrapper(1, 2, exposeFields=true, cacheSize=5000) is nearly equivalent with this Java code: obj = new com.example.MyObjectWrapper(1, 2); obj.setExposeFields(true); obj.setCacheSize(5000);

        • If you have no constructor arguments and property setters, and the className class has a public static INSTANCE field, the value of that filed will be the value of the expression, and the constructor won't be called.

        • If there exists a class named classNameBuilder, then that class will be instantiated instead with the given constructor arguments, and the JavaBean properties of that builder instance will be set. After that, the public build() method of the instance will be called, whose return value will be the value of the whole expression. (The builder class and the build() method is simply found by name, there's no special interface to implement.)Note that if you have a builder class, you don't actually need a className class (since 2.3.24); after all, classNameBuilder.build() can return any kind of object.

        • Currently, the values of arguments and properties can only be one of these:

          • A numerical literal, like 123 or -1.5. The value will be automatically converted to the type of the target (just like in FTL). However, a target type is only available if the number will be a parameter to a method or constructor, not when it's a value (or key) in a List or Map literal. Thus in the last case the type of number will be like in Java language, like 1 is an int, and 1.0 is a double, and 1.0f is a float, etc. In all cases, the standard Java type postfixes can be used ("f", "d", "l"), plus "bd" for BigDecimal and "bi" for BigInteger.
          • A boolean literal: true or false
          • The null literal: null
          • A string literal with FTL syntax, except that it can't contain ${...}-s. Examples: "Line 1\nLine 2" or r"C:\temp".
          • A list literal (since 2.3.24) with FTL-like syntax, for example [ 'foo', 2, true ]. If the parameter is expected to be array, the list will be automatically converted to array. The list items can be any kind of expression, like even object builder expressions.
          • A map literal (since 2.3.24) with FTL-like syntax, for example { 'foo': 2, 'bar': true }. The keys and values can be any kind of expression, like even object builder expressions. The resulting Java object will be a Map that keeps the item order (LinkedHashMap as of this writing).
          • A reference to a public static filed, like Configuration.AUTO_DETECT or com.example.MyClass.MY_CONSTANT.
          • An object builder expression. That is, object builder expressions can be nested into each other.
        • The same kind of expression as for parameters can also be used as top-level expressions (though it's rarely useful, apart from using null).

        • The top-level object builder expressions may omit ().

        • The following classes can be referred to with simple (unqualified) name instead of fully qualified name: DefaultObjectWrapper, DefaultObjectWrapper, RestrictedObjectWrapper, Locale, TemplateConfiguration, PathGlobMatcher, FileNameGlobMatcher, PathRegexMatcher, AndMatcher, OrMatcher, NotMatcher, ConditionalTemplateConfigurationFactory, MergingTemplateConfigurationFactory, FirstMatchTemplateConfigurationFactory, HTMLOutputFormat, XMLOutputFormat, RTFOutputFormat, PlainTextOutputFormat, UndefinedOutputFormat, Configuration, TemplateLanguage, TagSyntax.

        • TimeZone objects can be created like TimeZone("UTC"), despite that there's no a such constructor.

        • Charset objects can be created like Charset("ISO-8859-5"), despite that there's no a such constructor.

        • The classes and methods that the expression meant to access must be all public.

        Overrides:
        setSetting in class MutableProcessingConfiguration<SelfT extends MutableParsingAndProcessingConfiguration<SelfT>>
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the setting.
        value - the string that describes the new value of the setting.
        Throws:
        InvalidSettingNameException - if the name is wrong.
        InvalidSettingValueException - if the new value of the setting can't be set for any other reasons.
        ConfigurationException

        public void unsetTagSyntax()
        Resets the setting value as if it was never set (but it doesn't affect the value inherited from another ParsingConfiguration).

      • getTagSyntax

        public TagSyntax getTagSyntax()
        Description copied from interface: ParsingConfiguration
        Determines the syntax of the template files (angle bracket VS square bracket) that has no #ftl in it. The tagSyntax parameter must be one of:
        • TagSyntax.AUTO_DETECT: use the syntax of the first FreeMarker tag (can be anything, like #list, #include, user defined, etc.)
        • TagSyntax.ANGLE_BRACKET: use the angle bracket syntax (the normal syntax)
        • TagSyntax.SQUARE_BRACKET: use the square bracket syntax

        In FreeMarker 2.3.x TagSyntax.ANGLE_BRACKET is the default for better backward compatibility. Starting from 2.4.x TagSyntax.AUTO_DETECT is the default, so it's recommended to use that even for 2.3.x.

        This setting is ignored for the templates that have ftl directive in it. For those templates the syntax used for the ftl directive determines the syntax.

        Specified by:
        getTagSyntax in interface ParsingConfiguration

      • getDefaultTagSyntax

        protected abstract TagSyntax getDefaultTagSyntax()
        Returns the value the getter method returns when the setting is not set, possibly by inheriting the setting value from another ParsingConfiguration, or throws CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

        public SelfT outputFormat(OutputFormat outputFormat)

      • getOutputFormat

        public OutputFormat getOutputFormat()
        Description copied from interface: ParsingConfiguration
        The output format to use, which among others influences auto-escaping (see ParsingConfiguration.getAutoEscapingPolicy() autoEscapingPolicy}), and possibly the MIME type of the output.

        On the Configuration level, usually, you should leave this on its default, which is UndefinedOutputFormat.INSTANCE, and then use standard file extensions like "ftlh" (for HTML) or "ftlx" (for XML) (and ensure that recognizeStandardFileExtensions is true; see more there). Where you can't use the standard extensions, templates still can be associated to output formats with patterns matching their name (their path) using the templateConfigurations setting of the Configuration. But if all templates will have the same output format, you may set the outputFormat setting of the Configuration after all, to a value like HTMLOutputFormat.INSTANCE, XMLOutputFormat.INSTANCE, etc. Also note that templates can specify their own output format like <#ftl outputFormat="HTML">, which overrides any configuration settings.

        Specified by:
        getOutputFormat in interface ParsingConfiguration
        See Also:
        Configuration.getRegisteredCustomOutputFormats(), Configuration.getTemplateConfigurations(), ParsingConfiguration.getRecognizeStandardFileExtensions(), ParsingConfiguration.getAutoEscapingPolicy()

      • getSourceEncoding

        public Charset getSourceEncoding()
        Description copied from interface: ParsingConfiguration
        Sets the charset used for decoding template files.

        Defaults to "UTF-8". (On some desktop applications Charset.defaultCharset() is maybe preferable.)

        When a project contains groups (like folders) of template files where the groups use different encodings, consider using the templateConfigurations setting on the Configuration level.

        Individual templates may specify their own charset by starting with <#ftl sourceEncoding="...">. However, before that's detected, at least part of template must be decoded with some charset first, so this setting (and templateConfigurations) still have role.

        Specified by:
        getSourceEncoding in interface ParsingConfiguration

      • getDefaultSourceEncoding

        protected abstract Charset getDefaultSourceEncoding()
        Returns the value the getter method returns when the setting is not set, possibly by inheriting the setting value from another ParsingConfiguration, or throws CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • setSourceEncoding

        public void setSourceEncoding(Charset sourceEncoding)
        The charset to be used when reading the template "file" that the TemplateLoader returns as binary (InputStream). If the #ftl header specifies an charset, that will override this.

        Resets the setting value as if it was never set (but it doesn't affect the value inherited from another ParsingConfiguration).

      • getTabSize

        public int getTabSize()
        Description copied from interface: ParsingConfiguration
        The assumed display width of the tab character (ASCII 9), which influences the column number shown in error messages (or the column number you get through other API-s). So for example if the users edit templates in an editor where the tab width is set to 4, you should set this to 4 so that the column numbers printed by FreeMarker will match the column number shown in the editor. This setting doesn't affect the output of templates, as a tab in the template will remain a tab in the output too. The value of this setting is at least 1, and at most 256. When it's 1, tab characters will be kept in the return value of Template.getSource(int, int, int, int), otherwise they will be replaced with the appropriate number of spaces.
        Specified by:
        getTabSize in interface ParsingConfiguration

      • getDefaultTabSize

        protected abstract int getDefaultTabSize()
        Returns the value the getter method returns when the setting is not set, possibly by inheriting the setting value from another ParsingConfiguration, or throws CoreSettingValueNotSetException.
